posts.title: Advanced Memory Management in C++: Stack vs. Heap
posts.content:
In C++, memory management is a cornerstone for developing high-performance and stable applications. Efficient memory usage, preventing leaks, and optimization are critical, especially in systems programming and industrial applications.

Stack and Heap Memory Areas

Stack: Used for static memory allocation. Function calls and local variables are stored here. It provides fast access but has a limited size, which is known at compile time.

Heap: Used for dynamic memory allocation. It is managed via new and delete operators. Ideal for large data structures and objects whose size is not known at compile time, but it is slower and more complex to manage.

Smart Pointers

In modern C++, smart pointers that apply the RAII (Resource Acquisition Is Initialization) principle are used to prevent memory leaks:

  • unique_ptr: A single ownership model. It automatically releases memory when the object it points to goes out of scope. It cannot be copied, only moved.
  • shared_ptr: A shared ownership model. It keeps a reference counter. The counter increments as you copy the pointer and decrements when a copy is destroyed. Memory is released when the counter reaches zero. Be cautious of circular dependency risks.
  • weak_ptr: Used in conjunction with shared_ptr but does not share ownership. It's ideal for breaking circular references.

posts.title: Modern State Management in React: Hooks & Context API
posts.content:
React is one of the most popular libraries for modern web development with its component-based architecture. As application complexity grows, managing data flow and state between components can become challenging. In this post, we'll explore the modern state management solutions offered by React.

Essential Hooks

  • useState: Used to manage local state in functional components. It returns a state variable and a function to update it.
  • useEffect: Used to perform side effects after a component renders. Operations like API requests, DOM manipulations, or subscriptions are managed here.

Context API for Global State

Instead of passing state deep down the component tree (prop drilling), the Context API is used to create a globally accessible state. A Provider component provides the state, and any component in the tree can access this state using the useContext hook. It offers a simple alternative to external libraries like Redux.

posts.title: gRPC vs. REST API: Which One to Choose?
posts.content:
When developing microservice architectures and modern APIs, gRPC and REST are two of the most common standards. While both offer powerful solutions, they are designed for different scenarios.

REST (Representational State Transfer)

REST is a simple and flexible architectural style built on the HTTP protocol. It typically exchanges data in JSON format and uses standard HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE). Its human-readability and broad browser support make it a popular choice for general-purpose APIs.

  • Advantages: Simplicity, flexibility, wide compatibility, stateless nature.
  • Disadvantages: Text-based JSON format can be slower, unidirectional communication.

gRPC (Google Remote Procedure Call)

gRPC is a high-performance RPC (Remote Procedure Call) framework developed by Google. It uses Protocol Buffers (Protobuf) for data serialization and runs on HTTP/2. This enables advanced features like a binary data format and bidirectional streaming.

  • Advantages: High performance, low latency, bidirectional streaming, strong type safety.
  • Disadvantages: Limited browser support (requires a proxy), binary format is not human-readable.

When to Choose Which?

  • REST: Ideal for public APIs, web clients (browsers), and simple data CRUD operations.
  • gRPC: Perfect for communication between microservices, mobile applications, real-time applications, and high-performance scenarios requiring low latency.

posts.title: Core Concepts of Spring Boot: What Every Developer Should Know
posts.content:
Spring Boot is a framework that dramatically simplifies the development of modern, robust applications in the Java ecosystem. But what are the core concepts behind this power?

Dependency Injection (DI) and Inversion of Control (IoC)

IoC is the principle where an object delegates the responsibility of creating its dependencies to an external force (the Spring IoC Container). Dependency Injection is a way to implement this principle. Spring automatically 'injects' the objects a class needs using the @Autowired annotation. This promotes loose coupling between classes and increases testability.

Auto-Configuration

This is one of Spring Boot's most magical features. It automatically configures the beans and settings your application might need by looking at the JAR files in your project's classpath. For example, if you add Spring Data JPA to your project, it will prepare all the necessary configuration for a database connection for you.

Layered Architecture and Annotations

Spring Boot supports a layered architecture and provides a set of useful annotations to manage these layers:

  • @RestController: Indicates that a class hosts RESTful API endpoints.
  • @Service: Represents the business logic layer.
  • @Repository: Marks the data access layer (DAO).
  • @Component: A generic component that should be managed by Spring.

posts.title: The Power of .NET: Why It's More Than Just C#
posts.content:
.NET (formerly .NET Core) is an open-source platform from Microsoft for building modern, cross-platform, and high-performance applications. Let's look at some of the key features that make it so powerful.

High Performance

Modern .NET is one of the fastest backend frameworks available. Thanks to the Kestrel web server, an optimized JIT (Just-In-Time) compiler, and memory management improvements, it provides maximum efficiency with minimal resources. This makes it ideal for high-traffic APIs and microservices.

Middleware Pipeline

In ASP.NET Core, every incoming HTTP request passes through a middleware pipeline. Each middleware component can inspect, modify, or pass the request to the next component. This structure makes it easy to manage cross-cutting concerns like authentication, logging, and caching in a modular way.

Built-in Dependency Injection (DI)

Like Spring Boot, .NET comes with a built-in Dependency Injection container. By registering your services in the Program.cs (or Startup.cs) file, you can have them automatically injected into any constructor or method that needs them. This encourages writing flexible and testable code.

Entity Framework Core (EF Core)

EF Core is a modern ORM (Object-Relational Mapper) for .NET. It allows you to write SQL queries directly in C# code using LINQ (Language-Integrated Query). By mapping database tables to C# classes, it abstracts and simplifies database operations.
